It appears to me that Boris will simply get out of an extension using EU law. The commission can only negotiate with the UK government as it’s interlocutor. It cannot negotiate with the British Parliament. The Benn Act requires Boris to send a letter to Commission stating the parliament has requested an extension. Parliament cannot request that the government has requested this extension as the whole cabinet voted against the Benn Act. All Boris has to do is hand in the letter and explain this is not the view of the UK government and I am not asking for this extension. This then puts the EU in a bind as they cannot deal with anyone other than Boris and the government.
The only way around this would be for the opposition parties to topple Boris and install a caretaker government who could hand in the letter. Time for this is now very short and moreover the opposition is completely divided.

@Steve Creaton: Their is nothing stopping the EU agreeing an extension offer ( I would suggest a good year or two) and presenting it to Boris publicly. He is probably the only one who can ask but there is no problem with us offering.

@Steve Creaton: The opposition are definitely not “completely divided”. They are United in trying to prevent a no deal Brexit as the Benn Act proves. They are in disagreement over who should be the caretaker Prime Minister when they topple Bojo but otherwise they are completely United…

@jackbello: I see once again you are choosing to simply ignore reality. Under WTO Rules and Terms of Conditions which the UK will be obliged to obey if they wish to trade within the WTO, they must impose tarriffs on all goods entering the UK from the EU or if they choose not to impose tarriffs, they must give “without exception” give the same conditions to “every WTO member state” that the UK wish to trade with.
As this would be economic suicide for the UK it would be very unlikely. So with Tarrifs comes Customs checks at the point of entry, ie: The Border. There is no getting around that fact.

@jackbello: If the UK want to operate under WTO rules then they will have to erect a border. Otherwise they would be treating Ireland differently than other countries in the organisation, which is in direct violation of “Most Favoured Nation” WTO legislature.
Meaning the UK in breach of WTO rules and membership suspended.

His proposed alternative to the backstop – another backstop that would place the onus on regulatory alignment on Ireland, to a UK playbook, rather than on the UK, to the EU playbook – is an absolute farce. It’s deeply sad to see critics of our government seemingly embracing that idea as ‘sensible’ or ‘reasonable’ – however much you might dislike this government, accepting that arrangement is effectively acknowledging that British sovereignty should be respected as superior to Irish sovereignty. If that backstop of Boris’ is supposed to be good enough for Ireland, the original backstop in the withdrawal agreement should be perfectly acceptable to the UK – anything else is completely hypocritical.
Proposals like that, by the way, are precisely why Ireland cannot afford to simply rely on ‘goodwill’ in terms of protection of the GFA – if ideas like that count as ‘reasonable’ in the current UK government’s thinking, we absolutely need legally binding agreements that sort out the issues upfront, and a status-quo fallback if agreement cannot be reached.

A border poll only becomes more likely if there is a Hard Brexit and could only realistically occur as part of the dispute solving mechanism built into the Good Friday Agreement. This process would take years to complete.
In any case it could only realistically pass if the financial hardship in the North, post Brexit, were to prove enough to sway moderate Protestants/Unionists against the Union and towards the Republic. It would also certainly require major concessions on the Catholic/Republican side as regards minority protections for the various issues we disagree on but they hold dear to their hearts. This could a tough sell in the Republic and so all of this would need to be carefully plotted out, presumably by some sort of combined All-Ireland Commission, to give it a realistic chance of a success.

The Sacred cow and the Dairy Farmer.
A Dairy farmer is probably the most important, person on the planet and receives some of the least earnings, 70% of the world depend on milk, cheese cream and other dairy products. Dairy farmers/workers have to rise out of bed early to milk their cows, and then are depending on fetching a decent price for their product, Cows need to be impregnated and get pregnant to produce milk, calves are born and reared for a period of time then sold off to a beef farmer who fattens the up for sale to meat producers.
Again depending on market prices whether or not a profit is materialized, The meat is processed and sold on, butchers etc. And as a butcher by trade, I can ask this question.
Who really makes the most money, out of it all ?. There is very little left to waste. But the hide, pelt, (skin of both beef and sheep, and other animals) can return hefty profits for some, as in shoes, coats, bags, belts, etc. Many items fetching Thousands of Euro’s dollars etc
Imagine if a Dairy farmer, Beef farmer, even the butchers, was to receive a tiny percentage, from all concerned along the way, from the beef farmer, dairy producers, butchers, tanners, to the cobbler and more. That would give some a nice extra income,
It sickens me when actors etc get paid every time they are on screen, in repeats, or sports stars doing promotions adds etc. Imagine if your electrician charged you every time you turned on your lights, TV, computer, cooker, microwave, fridge etc, Or the plumber charged for every shower, bath, every flush of the toilet, using a garden hose etc, or the carpenter when you opened or closed a door, window walked on the floor. We take all these for granted, and they the low earners.
But don’t seemly have a problem, handing over money, to go to movies theaters, pay outlandish prices for clothing or attire, for some celebrities name or image on it, I know a number of people that are happy to pay a TV subscription of over €100.00 a month, for movie, sports channels, a similar expense on phones, and yet can be behind in rent utility bills, short of food, and decent clothing.
Television has been the great influence in our lives for close on or more than 70 years. But there is very little new out there, so many repeats, some on a weekly basis, Shown on a Sunday again on a Thursday. The same actors and crew getting paid over and over again. Making some very rich indeed.
Chat show hosts, getting outrageous money for a couple of hours work, whether they are actually entertaining or not, There are enough companies paying for Add minutes between breaks, who depend on the exposure, to pay for the lot, the host crew, , tv license etc etc, the add’s interruption of shows, can actually be construed as an invasion of your privacy, of an invasion of your, enjoyment, a means to mind suggestion and mental control, if they induce you to react and purchase, or contribute. Some companies should be taken to court in a class action suit, by people who have been influenced by their manipulation of you in your own house, or where ever you are watching.
The phone networks are another example of been manipulated, with all these plans they are promoting, If one doesn’t make that many calls or sent many texts in a month, it can work out very expensive for the calls and texts that are made, they offer a Data allowance, but very often, unavailable when actually needed.
I have yet to enjoy a full weekend of the free Data allowance that I am supposed to enjoy.

Arlene Foster is touring the countryside in her Chauffeur driven car.
Suddenly a cow jumps out into the road. They hit it full on and the car comes to a stop.
Arlene in her usual charming manner, says to the chauffeur…….
“You get out and check – you were driving.”
The chauffeur gets out, checks and reports that the animal is dead. “You were driving; go and tell the farmer,” says Arlene
Five hours later the chauffeur returns totally plastered, his hair ruffled and with a big grin on his face.

The chauffeur replies: “When I got there, the farmer opened his best bottle of malt whisky, the wife gave me a slap-up meal and the daughter made love to me.”
“What on earth did you say?” asks Arlene

“I’m Arlene Foster’s chauffeur and I’ve just killed the cow.”

Like everything else, Boris hasn’t thought this through. The sea at the closest point between Scotland and Ireland is about 1000 feet deep. Now the Pylons supporting the Bridge would have to be driven into the sea bed to a depth of around 300 feet and add another 200 feet above the waterline to allow shipping to pass freely. So your Pylons would have to be around 1500 feet long and about 50 feet in diameter each. Each one would have to be able to take hurricane force winds and wave action without snapping like a twig during winter storms. Add to this the length of the Bridge span at 22 miles. So during storm conditions the Bridge would have to be closed to traffic for safety reasons (most winters). Now add in the further complication of all the unused unexploded ammunition and explosives dumped by the Royal Navy in the area over the past 80 years. Then you would have the cost of Maintance.
So the idea of a bridge is pure fantasy land stuff.

“Hotel California”
On a dark desert highway, cool wind in my hair
Warm smell of colitas, rising up through the air
Up ahead in the distance, I saw a shimmering light
My head grew heavy and my sight grew dim
I had to stop for the night
There she stood in the doorway
I heard the mission bell
And I was thinking to myself
“This could be Heaven or this could be Hell”
Then she lit up a candle and she showed me the way
There were voices down the corridor
I thought I heard them say
Welcome to the Hotel California
Such a lovely place (Such a lovely place)
Such a lovely face
Plenty of room at the Hotel California
Any time of year (Any time of year)
You can find it here
Her mind is Tiffany-twisted, she got the Mercedes bends
She got a lot of pretty, pretty boys she calls friends
How they dance in the courtyard, sweet summer sweat
Some dance to remember, some dance to forget
So I called up the Captain
“Please bring me my wine.”
He said, “We haven’t had that spirit here since nineteen sixty nine.”
And still those voices are calling from far away
Wake you up in the middle of the night
Just to hear them say
Welcome to the Hotel California
Such a lovely place (Such a lovely place)
Such a lovely face
They livin’ it up at the Hotel California
What a nice surprise (what a nice surprise)
Bring your alibis
Mirrors on the ceiling
The pink champagne on ice
And she said “We are all just prisoners here, of our own device”
And in the master’s chambers
They gathered for the feast
They stab it with their steely knives
But they just can’t kill the beast
Last thing I remember
I was running for the door
I had to find the passage back to the place I was before
“Relax,” said the night man
“We are programmed to receive
You can check-out any time you like
But you can never leave!”

The backstop is a way for the UK to meet all its legal obligations until it can find another way to meet them. It keeps Northern Ireland (or the entire UK if they prefer) in the Customs Union until they can figure out how to leave the Customs Union without restricting trade or travel in the island of Ireland.
If the UK comes up with that solution today, next week or in five years, the backstop will no longer be needed.
Putting a time-limit on it means that if they don’t come up with a solution in whatever time is allowed, then they run into the same problems they’re having now. And, by definition, would have no solution except to beg for the backstop to be extended.

The convention is that the Member of Parliament who is Speaker is not opposed by any of the main parties at a general election so is returned automatically. However, Andrea Leadsom, Boris’s Business Secretary, has said that Bercow will be opposed at the next election. As he is a Tory M.P. that suggests that he will be deselected by his constituency Conservative Party Branch. There is no way that Bercow would stand as an Independent so we can expect an announcement of his intention to resign as an M.P. next. Another convention is that an ex-Speaker is sent to the House of Lords but that looks unlikely for Bercow.

A no deal Brexit with a low exchange rate for sterling will therefore be brilliant for the UK.
Irish exports to the UK will be too expensive for UK buyers.

@m flynsk: The cost of inputs will be massive as the currency is worth less.

@m flynsk: that’s only a temporary effect. Imports become more expensive and that introduces inflation (the prices of everything that have components from ‘abroad’ goes up)
That puts pressure on wages as the earned pound needs to stretch further as prices go up.
The temporary spike (before inflation kicks in) will be used by BJ and his clowns to claim that everything is fine and ‘we’re winning’
I’m not an economist but that’s my understanding and what I expect to happen

Johnson smiled as Varadkar made the comment, although it is unclear whether it was because the British prime minister was pleased to see Varadkar aping the Johnson style of frequently quoting the classics, or whether he had really taken in the implications of what the Irish prime minister had just said.
In Greek mythology, the goddess Athena did assist Hercules as an ally during the performance of his 12 labours. She provided, for example, bronze krotala – noise-makers similar to castanets – to help him scare off the flock of Stymphalian birds. And in some versions of the tale she was also of service to him by returning to their rightful place the golden apples of the gods that Hercules had been asked to obtain.
But it is perhaps her most dramatic intervention in the life of Hercules that Varadkar was obliquely referring to.
Hercules was obliged to perform the 12 labours as an act of penitence after he had descended into madness and murdered his wife, Megara, and his children. At the moment he was about to go on and kill the man who had fostered him, Amphitryon, Athena intervened. Seeing that he had gone mad, she struck Hercules down and knocked him out to prevent him causing more bloodshed and doing more damage than he had already done.
Source: The Guardian

FG and the EU need to be honest now and tell us what the insistence on the backstop and the pledge to keep a frictionless border between the Republic and NI is going to mean in the event of a no-deal Brexit. It hasn’t been publicly spoken about but the whispers have been going for months. If the WA is not changed sufficiently to allow the UK to sign up to it, the EU have privately said that while they are wiling to take a short-term wait and see approach to a frictionless border, they would not tolerate it long-term. They cannot allow a situation where a country not in the customs union/single market has a channel for the free-flow of goods unchecked into the EU. If the Irish government continue to insist on a frictionless border then the only way to ensure unchecked goods are not reaching the other 26 member states is to have checks on ALL Irish goods at ports of entry to the rest of the EU. This would make ‘just in time’ deliveries to the continent impossible. It would be an absolute disaster for Ireland and the UK government know this. Add to this that poll results in the UK suggest that the outcome of a general election would be a Bojo led Conservative/Brexit party coalition. Even Corbyn realises this, which is why he has dropped the idea of a no-confidence motion which would bring about an election. I really do support the idea of the backstop, but with it in place a no-deal Brexit is inevitable and it’s us who will suffer as a result. Almost chokes me to say this, but Bojo is playing a blinder here.

@Tommy Roche: truth is, we should protect our relationship with Europe above our relationship with NI.
We can’t allow a basket case NI and a lunatic Britain to drag us out of the single market.

@Adam Kelly: Couldn’t agree more. Problem is, how can the EU allow free movement of goods from the Republic, where, in the event of a no-deal Brexit we insist on keeping an open border with a state not in the single market ? It can’t be done. Isn’t that what we’ve been telling the UK for the past 3 years ? That ,other than physical checks, the technology does not exist that could ensure that goods coming into the Republic from NI met with the regulatory requirements of the customs union/single market ? Hence the backstop and keeping NI aligned with EU regulations. But the backstop isn’t going to happen. It’s either remove it which means NI ‘could possibly’ be out of the single market after the transition period ends and no trade deal has been struck which would negate the need for checks on cross-border goods, or leave it in which means a no-deal Brexit and NI out of the single market in 8 weeks time. It doesn’t make sense to just sit back and do nothing, in the hope that the UK parliament will suddenly have a change of heart and vote to ratify an agreement they’ve rejected 3 times already. Or hope that UK politics implodes and Brexit is cancelled. That’s not going to happen either.

Is the EU that terrible that one dislikes it as much as the Brexiteers in the UK? I think the UK population are in for a shock when they leave the EU’s protective umbrella. I can explain the reasons, there are a lot of YouTube videos and articles written by experts that explain it. The two biggest reasons for war in the world is religion and trade. The world is full of trading blocks by geographical area like MERCOSUR, ASEAN, TPP, SADEC, or EU and the reason for that is supply chains. The bigger a trade area’s supply chain infrastructure, the more powerful is its manufacturing output. Ireland is a very small country, but it can source components from the rest of the EU in on-time delivery. Its going to be a big problem for Ireland as Britain acted as the gateway to EU marketplace by road and rail infrastucture. But the EU seem to want Ireland to remain a member and appear willing to invest billions in Ireland, for example, their pledge to give Irish farmers EU subsidies in the event of a no-deal Brexit. Ireland’s ports will have to be ready to bypass the UK and I just wonder how the EU and ROI are going to solve that. The EU are either going to pay Irish farmers EU subsidies forever, or they are going to find a way for Irish farmers to export fresh produce to the EU marketplace without it spoiling. Its a huge topic, an interesting one, and its interesting to note the majority of the world’s wars have been over religion or trade.

I think a no-deal Brexit is best as I think Europe is where Ireland needs to concentrate its trade with in the future, not with the UK. I feel sorry for those who lose their jobs over it. The EU is what I call a necessary evil in the 21st century. A European country like Denmark, Ireland, Sweden, or France can’t compete with the rest of the world by themselves. China now builds stealth aircraft, renewables, advanced electronics, and so on. There are also many trade blocks similar to the EU in the world like ASEAN, MERCORSUR, TPP, and so on. They are all divided by geographical area, main reason for that are supply chain networks. Most importantly it protects European trade. An IT company in Ireland will struggle to compete with an Indian IT company if India is granted access to services. The only time Indians are used like in call-centers are by European companies operating in Ireland. We can’t pretend that globalism doesn’t exist. Its unfortuante Trump is giving the English the wrong impression as the USA is a huge country with a massive GDP, its practically the same size as the EU, if not bigger. People don’t have a say generally over trade deals, for example, India has demanded easier work VISA access if Britain wants a trade deal with them. 80% of British trade consists of the services sector. Is the British government going to give the British public a referendum on that? I think its decided by trade negotiators. WTO-only rules is awful, because it means one has to apply the same tarriffs to every country in the world! I realise freedom of movement of people upsets some. @Paul O’Sullivan:
What complete and utter twaddle.
As defined in the Good Friday agreement which was approved by 95% of the Irish electorate and 75% of the Northern Irish Electorate:
1) Northern Ireland is part of the United Kingdom.
2) A border poll will take place when the NI secretary of state believes that a majority of the NI population wish to leave the UK
3) If a Border poll takes place, and the majority vote against leaving the UK, another poll cannot be called for at least 7 years.
No sane person in Ireland wants to leave the EU. In under 50 years the EU has brought Ireland from being a tiny backward agricultural economy to one of the richest per capita countries in the world.
Unless you live in Dublin Zoo, that “elephant in the room” is in your fairly vivid imagination.

micro economic & social policies.

wishes.

systemic risk.
We simply don’t want anothe EU harsh commercial response to EU/UK Brexit damage

etc.
Irish taxpayers are still paying dearly for te EU terms/conditions of the Celtic Tiger

As an aside, Irish customs are continually telling people that they cannot bring more than 200 cigarettes into Ireland even from another EU country. This is untrue. Under EU law, an EU country can put limits on the amount of tobacco or alcohol you can bring into that country, but the limits much be AT LEAST, 800 cigarettes, 1kg of tobacco, 10 litres of spirits, 90 litres of wine and 110 litres of beer. These are the minimums a country can set as limits. I don’t know if customs agents at Irish ports/airports are misinformed or are deliberately misleading people.

Basic no deal issues effecting companies:
Company or parent company incorporated in the UK: No longer valid company, must be reincorporated within the EU. Which means lots of paper pushing: New Company No, VAT No, Employer No etc. Source: Revenue.
Company transfers money via SEPA to/from GB accounts: UK will fallout of the system. Each individual UK PSP (bank) needs to reapply for membership as a non EEA member. Non EEA SEPA thansfers require additional Money Laundering details. Eg Address, BIC. Source: EPC white paper on Brexit.
All this before dealing with import issues.

Article is long and through, but I’m kinda lost in a verdict.
Firstly if current EU regulations require country symbol to be displayed within the number plate when driving abroad, then vast majority of UK drivers when abroad break this rule, as UK number plates with GB symbol included in them are extremely rare. So that means that thousands of UK drivers abroad already are breaking the law.
And secondly if EU regulation stop apply after UK is gone from EU, then we revert to Vienna convention regulations which in fact state exact same thing – that GB symbol has to be either displayed or included in the number plate.

The DUP have always been against the Good Friday Agreement. Thats why Arlene Foster and Jeffrey Donaldson left the Unionist Party and joined the DUP in the first place. They only worked the Agreement under threat from the two governments of the day but, now that things have changed, their long term aspiration to get rid of the GFA is now within their grasp. Of course they want Brexit and as hard a border as possible and also Direct Rule. In their minds, this cements their long-term place in the UK just when the numbers are changing dramatically in the North and a border poll looms at some stage.

Once the UK leaves the EU then direct rule for Northern Ireland takes on a totally new frontier unlike any previous joint administration. The Good Friday Agreement will need to be reviewed in the light of new circumstances and cannot simply be patched up. Better if Brexit was scrapped altogether, but that could be just wishful thinking.
United Ireland Referendum to follow.

@Caroline Broadhurst:
Before any agreement can be made on a united Ireland, the people of Northern Ireland need to vote to indicate that they wish to leave the UK and to form part of a united Ireland. That can only be done when the Northern Ireland Secretary of State believes that such a majority is likely. Not possible but “likely”. I would imagine that many opinion polls would need to show a consistent 60% to 70% in favour, before any Northern Ireland Secretary of State will call a border poll. That won’t be for a long while, if ever.
After that the fun begins. The UK will have to put legislation in place to accommodate NI leaving the UK leaving (think Brexit here), Ireland and Northern Ireland would have to come to some sort of an agreement as to what a united Ireland would look like. There would be a number of constitutional referenda required in Ireland. which would have to pass here.
A united island of Ireland under a single jurisdiction is a very long way off.

selecting a drug a patient responds to with minimal side effects can be a difficult task, particularly when the patient has co-morbidities and needs several drugs, which may interact.
Branded drugs are preferable as the physician knows the exact content of each active principle and its excipients. Alternative brands, though cheaper, may not report contents accurately and may not be best for an individual patient

@Anne Warren: Can you state your source on this please? Having worked in the healthcare sector for over 25 years I would have to disagree with this. Otherwise this kind of statement does no good and only causes distress and worry for patients.

@Anne Warren: Waffle. The entire point behind a generic is that it is the exact same chemical composition as the branded. Generics do not need stringent clinical trials because the side effects are exactly the same as the branded. With the exception of very few formulations and biosimilars, there is no justification for not prescribing a non branded medication.

I’m almost sick of repeating that it’s wrong to refer to any border as an “Irish Border “. The reality is, assuming the U.K. departs the EU without a deal, the resultant border will be an EU border between a member and a non-member state. It is no more difficult than that and both trading entities on either side of such a border will be obliged to honour their respective rights and obligations under the single market and customs union as operates on the EU side of the border. As a non Irish is for me the question for a United Ireland impossible to answer. Everibody wish a united Ireland, but how. I remember the same in Germany in 1990. Everybody was happy until the bill was presented to the West Germans. There had to be billions to be invested in the old DDR. and the peolple from the Ost didn’t have the money. For years Germany could not keep his inflation to the maximum 3%. The taxes became very hight in the West, In the Ost the unemployment rose. The different in wages had to be balanced over many years. In other words, the Ost Germans were a lot better off, they kept there homes free of mortgages, farmers became millionaires, while in the West their was struggle. I worked in Germany years later and I could feel the impact to the German people. Even now the Germans from the old DDR, are in the Bundes Republic still count as THey from the Ost. even after 25 years.
So an Unification is not so simple and should take years of preparation. Let us learn from the rush mistake in 1990. Make a United Ireland, but prepare yourself. Like I say, I am not an Irish citizen but life and worked here for more than 25 years. I am happy to life here, if not I was long gone.

Hey! I’m just a reader with limited migration knowledge but, has anyone read about the “Dormant Citizenship”?
Quote: “The concept of a “dormant citizenship” means that a person has the citizenships of two countries, but as long as he/she lives permanently in the one country, his/her status and citizens’ rights in the other country are “inactive.” They will be “reactivated” when he/she moves back to and lives permanently in the other country. This means, in spite of dual citizenship, only one citizenship can be exercised at a time.
The “dormant citizenship” exists for example in Spain: Spanish citizens who have naturalized in an Iberoamerican country and have kept their Spanish citizenship are technically dual citizens, but have lost their rights as Spanish—and EU—citizens until they move back to and live permanently in Spain”
Taken from https://noordinjella.livejournal.com/83398.html but you can google it.
Perhaps each country decides if the dormant citizenship rule applies in their territory. I am citizen of 3 countries and I am aware that two of them applies this rule.

@bopter : “And if *your* mother tongue is English, we would love it if your grammar was also reasonably good English.” – Starting a sentence with a conjunction. Frowned upon, especially in written communication, but not technically grammatically incorrect. Asterisks as parentheses ie; (*your*) is doubly incorrect. Asterisks are used chiefly to indicate an omission, a reference to a footnote, or an unattested word, sound, or affix. Parentheses, or brackets, are used to convey additional information which can be removed without altering the structure of the sentence. “…we would love it…”. Who constitutes this group you speak of? It’s not poor grammar but it leaves an unanswered question which is not good writing. Lastly “…if your grammar was also reasonably good English.”. There is no need to cite again that you are referring to the English language, I didn’t suddenly think you were chastising his grasp of Japanese, and if you must include it then you should write “…good English grammar.”. Overall a very unwieldy sentence with one glaring mistake. I hope this helps you with your trolling in the future.

Here’s the list of recess dates during this session of parliament, a session which is now the longest in 400 years.
https://www.parliament.uk/about/faqs/house-of-commons-faqs/business-faq-page/recess-dates/
Strange that we didn’t witness the same uproar when parliament took its traditional conference recess last Sept-Oct, or the Sept-Oct before that. In fact, every Sept-Oct in living memory. Remainers have been banging on about this traditional break all summer, trotting out it’s official name, Proroging, which very few had ever heard of, to make it appear like it was something unusual. Personally I think it’s ridiculous to take a recess at such a crucial time, but it’s worth remembering that not one remain supporting party cancelled their annual conference or called for the traditional Sept-Oct recess to be cancelled. They wanted it to go ahead so that it could be used as a political weapon. If people want to, rightly, point the finger at the Leave movement for sharp practice, then they have to also call this faux uproar of the past week for exactly what it is. A political set-up.

The main thing most people seem intent on avoiding or not seeing is the actual thing forcing the Brits out. And Im not saying its the boogy man they are portraying it to be, but the steady march towards a federalisation of Europe is behind all of this. The erosion of the sovereignty of the individual countries, and the rule of bureaucratic elites. I believe in a European Union, based on the co-operation of each individual state in a group, but not the co-option of the state into a federal entity which would always rule from afar, and rule to the whims of the most politically powerful countries. I believe in the single market, to a certain degree the concept of EU citizenship and the rights it conveys within the member states, but the interminable march into pushing back the boundaries of the states and their own influence on their internal policies and regulations needs to be brought to a halt. I believe it is desirous to have a Union of European states, with a common market and common goals. I just believe we have overshot that, and the medicine that was once prescribed to help overcome the struggles between Europes nation states, is not helping anymore. Its actually killing the patient. We need to row back to a point on the other side of the Lisbon treaty. We were right to refuse it the first time, and our own government and political classes in their eagerness to be part of the big experiment and be Good Europeans refused to bring our judgement of the situation to the bureaucracy and tell them we dont want this, and in truth neither did the populations of many other countries, but they were not offered referendums to show they didnt. Brexit is simply the first symptom of the ailment that is killing the patient, because they should have stopped taking the medicine when they were stable, but now they are hooked and simply cant see life as being livable without it.

A hard border may not be so bad if it ultimately leads to a united Ireland. But if people really don’t want the worst-case-scenario, sketched out by the British cabinet office, to materialise, the solution is for the “backstop” to apply only to Northern Ireland, and not to the UK as a whole (as it currently does because of the DUP’s counter-productive insistence, making the Withdrawal Agreement impossible for Westminster to agree to). If the backstop were to apply only to Northern Ireland (placing the border in the Irish Sea rather than a hard border on land), it would mean that everybody wins: the British people get their Brexit and the people of Northern Ireland (the majority of whom voted to remain in the EU) are saved from a hard border. Both Ireland and Britain would also benefit from an orderly Brexit.
@J. Reid: The “national security exception” in the World Trade Organisation rules (article 21 of the general agreement on tariffs and trade) could also be invoked in order to avoid a hard border.

“When 14-year-old Philip Rafferty left his home in west Belfast to go to band practice, his mother, Maureen, made sure he was wearing his new winter coat. The next time she saw it was in a plastic bag at his inquest, saturated with blood.
On January 30th, 1973, Philip was on his way home when he was abducted from the street by loyalist paramilitaries. He was taken to the Giant’s Ring, outside Belfast, where they hooded him with his coat, beat him, and then shot him several times.

Boris Johnson should just work with the majority of his own Conservative Party, and with those Labour Party MP’s who represent “Leave” constituencies, in addition to previously pro-remain Labour MP’s who simply respect the referendum result, to simply pass the Withdrawal Agreement that has already been agreed between the EU and the UK government under Johnson’s predecessor (Theresa May), and stay true to his pledge to take the UK out of the EU by October 31st “do or die”. If he does this, a British general election will be allowed to happen quickly afterwards and Johnson will probably be rewarded by the British public who will just be relieved that Brexit has been legally completed and they can move on to negotiating the most important thing which is the Free Trade Agreement.
The electoral threat from Nigel Farage will recede if Boris Johnson takes the UK out of the EU on October 31st, even under Theresa May’s Withdrawal Agreement, because even arch-Conservative voters will be happy that Johnson has actually managed to deliver some form of Brexit and the oxygen will largely be taken out of the issue. The alternative for Conservative voters, if they were to vote for Farage, would be to put Jeremy Corbyn in 10 Downing Street.
If Johnson returns with a Conservative Party majority after the UK general general election he will never again need the DUP who, actions speaking louder than words, have been the single biggest obstacle to Brexit. Negotiating a Free Trade Agreement will then be much easier.
As Angela Merkel pointed out on the phone to Boris Johnson today, if Germany wanted to leave the EU it would be perfectly possible for the Germans to leave the customs union; but with Britain’s border dividing the island of Ireland and with all of the issues this gives rise to in regard to peace and in regard to the integrity of the single market, it is simply not possible for Northern Ireland to leave the customs union. Johnson and, especially now, Labour Party MP’s, have to get to grips with the realty and should just pass May’s Withdrawal Agreement and move on.

They have a tortured new way to describe the customs arrangements for what would be in every way the northern Ireland only back stop without saying it. So NI would officially be part of the UK customs zone if the EU agreed not to collect tarrifs on NI goods entering the the republic while all Goods entering NI from the UK would have EU customs collected on them at the ports. The goods shipped to NI from UK would have customs rebates from the UK if they were proved to not enter the the republic. This is totally the border in the Irish sea and peace on the Island. It’s also brilliant for the North as in practice the UK won’t be able to figure out what goods are NI bound only so goods sent to the EU through NI will have a competitive advantage to those flowing to the EU from Britain directly.

The citizens’ assembly was a farce. We already have a citizens’ assembly: Dáil Éireann. But some people wanted to get around the representatives elected by the people and further their agenda. So they created the citizens’ assembly. Nobody elected these people. Most of the experts and politicians were selected by the government and only a minority were allegedly citizens’ selected by random. What about the six participants, allegedly from an apolitical background that were exposed to have Labour Party links, including a former local election candidate? What about the individual who had his friends be selected as representatives? The government set the agenda, what would be discussed. The citizens’ assembly proposed discussing several constitutional amendments, such as enshrining a constitutional right to housing etc. But the government nixed these. When you think about it, the citizens’ assembly was established at the height of the economic crisis when the Troika directed the country’s fiscal policies. Young people, who bore the brunt of the austerity measures, had little control over the situation. So, Fine Gael enthusiastically rowed in behind the citizens’ assembly, which focused exclusively on social issues which cost the State very little from a budgetary perspective, rather than a constitutional right to housing which could be very problematic. The citizens’ assembly was a media creation: it gave legitimacy to furthering this liberal agenda, which the media rowed in behind 100%. Of course those constitutional amendments were passed, the media and political elite were completely biased. There really wasn’t a choice. Just like the Troika/Bank guarantee: the media decreed that we had to accept the debts of Anglo Irish Bank and the people did. If you are so pleased with the citizens’ assembly, why not do away with Dáil Éireann entirely? The citizens’ assembly was just a means of legitimization outcomes predetermined by the Fine Gael government. It’s a fraud.

A proper journalist would have looked past the EU masters spin and found out that after Brexit if you are ordering from outside the UK, you will not be charged UK VAT (20%). So an item that cost £100 will now be £83.33, then when paying the Irish VAT (23%) its a total of £102.50.
Currently, when any trader in the EU delivers to another EU country, they have to charge the VAT rate at the delivery address, not the sender – so that item will cost £102.50 right now!
A grand increase of £0. Except the Irish government get the VAT.
Perhaps if we can pay VAT by text or email we would not be stung for the wholly unjustifiable An Post fee – and if all works out we would be no better, or worse off.

To all those folks who still think house prices are what they are… due to housing supply , allow me to educate you.
High House price rises are not due to supply (or lack thereof ) not due either 2 lack of land , or high immigrantion
The reason they have gone up is an over abundant supply of FAKE mortgage cash.
In the same way everything has gone up in price (in local currency ) in Zimbabwe or venezuala, so house prices have gone up all over the western world for the same reason .
I only learnt last year that when a mortgage is created – the actual cash is freshly minted ( in a vurtual sense) there and then by the private bank issuing the loan.
B4 the issuance of that mortgage, that money didn’t exist anywhere .
That banks have this power to lend money from nowhere – 2 create money from nowhere ,means that with time the buying power of said mortgage money keeps getting less and less as more mortgages and thus more freshly printed money is lent.
There was a time in the UK when the majority of mortgage money was issued by building societies
. From the 40s thru to the late 70s prices remained exactly in line with wages. It’s no coincidence that building societies unlike banks couldn’t and still can’t print money – they have to burrow it themselves or other depositers.
Since no new supply of money is involved in the issuance of these mortgages, the buying power of said cash remains constant and so consequently do house prices.
At the end of the 70s the banks were unleashed and the restrictions in mortgage lending were lifted ( the main restriction being that for every 1 pound lent in mortgages 4 times as much needs to be lent to industry ).
Good sensible laws preventing bank issued mortgage cash from the times of the 2nd world war were done away with , building societies were de mutualised and themselves became banks – and the flood of fake cash began.
Still ..
There is a bright side… when the supply or issuance of said mortgage reduces ( in another words we get credit de-acceraltion ) gdp drops and so do house prices.
We are seeing that now in the UK – and Ireland will soon follow suit . This is nothing to do with Brexit – but simply the phenomenon of what the economist prof minskey called ‘credit de-acceleration ‘

At this time of year parliament takes a 3.5 week break to allow for party conferences. Because parliament only sits 4 days per week, this effectively means that proroging parliament increased the non-sitting days by 5/6 days. This was a bizarre decision by the UK Supreme Court and is utterly inconsistent with precedent. In the first Miller case, they ruled that the conventions (as opposed to the legal rules) of the unwritten British Constitution were not justiciable (not a matter for the courts).
The prorogation of Parliament is a convention, not a legal rule. Also, the PM’s advice to the UK’s queen is a convention, and is not measured by a legal rule. But now the judges have radically changed their minds and have decided that the conventions are justiciable. This suggests that the court’s ruling is inherently political. This can only be read, by many, as a case of the establishment once again trying to thwart Brexit and to subvert the will of that country’s electorate.
@J. Reid: The effect of the prorogation was deemed unlawful.

The state of our Public Finances should already be sending alarm bells ringing, even before this happens.
There are 2 whoppers that the govt. have released on our Finances this year that show just how screwed we are:
- Between 2006 and 2018, Income & Corp tax take in Ireland increased 65% from €19.1bn to €31.6bn. Yet we still can’t fund our public services & social welfare…?
- In the same time period, when you exclude the net position on bank debt (-€30bn), our national debt went from €30bn to €175bn to fund capital expenditure and day-to-day expenses.
If we can’t fund our current cost of living in this booming economy, something major is going to have to give in any kind of slow down.

Don’t know that this is necessarily false. The British legal system is stating that anyone born in the north is automatically British and to identify as any other nationality you must pay £200 to renounce your British citizenship first. So, the GFA actually never granted any special status to people from the north vis-à-vis national identity. According to immigration law, being born in Britain does not automatically confer British citizenship. Your parents must be British or be in Britain legally, so this ruling could potentially have major implications for many people including children born to EU citizens. I had better start renouncing mine now before they come looking for me!

@Anne Marie Devlin: I’ve only looked at this fleetingly. Was there something about cost of recognising her husband as an Irish spouse was cheaper than a British spouse.
While the mechanisms seem to be there to stand by the GFA it seems to cost to have those rights awarded (correct me if I’m wrong). So the rights exist if you can pay for them seems to be the ruling

@Anne Marie Devlin: Yes and No.
Ms De Soussa and her parent(s) (presuming at least one was born in the 6 counties) were always considered British as of Birth, in the eyes of British law and indeed many other countries bar Ireland (least not officially) . Even with her entitlement to be Irish, since the day she was born, it did not revoke her British citizenship. GFA says NOTHING about that . There is a difference in what some one claims to be and the actual issue eg (bad example) I might say that I am not a Catholic, because I don’t practice, but, I was baptised as one and never really renounced it (not sure there is an official way unless I convert to another religion )
For immigration purposes, since she never left the UK, the EU courts would not, based on a very similar case before them in 2011, recognise the duel nationality (I would love to see what the courts would say in light of GFA ,however, I’d fear that they might accept the reasoning from the recent judgment)
The rule about not being automatically British, deals with stopping illegals claiming their child is British even if the parents only spent 1 day in Britain (they fixed their rules in 1986, we did it in 2004 for the same reason) . That non automatic issue is highly likely to have absolutely no bearing to Ms De Soussa even if she was born after 1986
Before the 2004 Irish Citizenship Act amendments , our Citizenship laws (1956 Act as amended) did NOT give automatic citizenship rights , as of birth, to the Irish in the 6 counties. This was given to anyone in the South .
What was given to the Nordies was that were “entitled” to be Irish and this would be proven by getting an Irish passport. I accept one might see little difference in that in practice, but there kinda is a difference, albeit a small one, Southerners as of birth were assumed to be Irish without the need of a passport, the Nordies had to get the passport.
That never meant the British would respect it though. How many Northern Irish sports stars were always assumed to be British , even if they clearly were of the other tribe? Legally, it was still accurate. But, hey, the Brits took a long time to accept our country’s proper title in the English Language, always abusing the use of the term Éire. The previous citizenship regime sought to ensure that the British could not claim that Ireland was claiming them (that did not stop them however)
“So, the GFA actually never granted any special status to people from the north”
Kinda, yes. Most People up North could always get Irish Citizenship, but GFA says it is automatic. Remember the journalist Brian Kennan, EAST Belfast man. His Irish passport probably saved him from certain death when he was kidnapped in the Lebanon in 1986
As for people in the North renouncing their British Citizenship, hmm, be careful,until there is something set in ink, you would hardly want the British to treat you lot as Foreigners once they leave the UK
